author: STAFF WRITERS
title: Avatar, Exorcist, Cloverfield: Movies that made people sick |
text:
MOST films affect us emotionally in one way or another, but a handful have affected people physically as well.
From leaving audience members spewing in their seats to making them faint in the foyer, these are the movies some people will remember for all the wrong reasons.
The Exorcist - 1973:
Linda Blair stars as the young girl possessed by the devil in the classic horror film, which was named by Entertainment Weekly as the scariest movie of all time.
In an article published in the New York Times on January 27, 1974, journalist Judy Quote: : “It’s been reported that once inside the theatre, a number of moviegoers vomited at the very graphic goings-on on screen. Others fainted, or left the theatre, nauseous and trembling, before the film was half over. Several people had heart attacks, a guard told me. One woman even had a miscarriage, he said.”
127 Hours - 2010:
James Franco stars as mountain climber Aron Ralston in this movie, which includes a rather graphic amputation scene.
For some audience members, though, the horrifying moment was a little too much to take, with reports of more than 15 people fainting and three people suffering seizures at different screenings.
“I started to feel like I was going to throw up,” audience member Courtney Phelps told The LA Times . “So I went to the bathroom, and then I started feeling dizzy and my heart started racing. I have never had, even remotely, an experience like this. I’m a television producer. I know this stuff is not real.”
Rowan Virbickas blacked out, fell to the ground and began convulsing after seeing the film in Sydney, reported the Herald Sun .
“Girls were screaming, everyone was panicking - an ambulance was called and everything,” he said.
“They thought I was having a seizure. When I came to, I remembered about 30 seconds of the footage.”
James Franco in 127 Hours, which featured a graphic amputation scene. Source: Supplied
Cloverfield - 2008:
The premise of the movie is that it’s footage from a handheld camera, filmed as a group of friends try to escape a monster that is rampaging through New York.
But the shaky footage not only terrified some audience members, it also caused them to vomit.
“My wife had to stop watching multiple times,” wrote blogger Dan Rua after seeing the film.
“The first girl we spoke to after the movie felt queasy. Someone was throwing up in the bathroom afterwards.”
Another audience member wrote on IMDB : “I had to get up and leave the theatre for nearly 20 minutes just to keep from hurling”.
According to Dr. Michael G. Stewart, the reaction was nothing more than “a classic case of vertigo”.
He told CNN at the time of the movie’s release that people going to see the film at the cinema should take a dose of anti-vertigo medicine beforehand.
“It might not protect you from all the symptoms, but it could, and it certainly can’t hurt,” he said.
It wasn’t the monster that was scary, it was the way it was filmed. Source: News Corp Australia
Freaks - 1932:
Starring actual sideshow performers who had physical abnormalities, this film was banned in some countries because it was simply too shocking.
After test audiences reacted with repulsion, the film was edited down from 90 minutes to 64 minutes, with a rather graphic castration scene being one of the first parts to go.
One woman even threatened to sue MGM after watching the movie, claiming it resulted in her having a miscarriage.
The film effectively killed director Tod Browning’s career.
The film has now become a cult classic. Source: Supplied
Avatar - 2009:
It may be the highest grossing film in history, but it’s also responsible for the death of a Taiwanese man.
The 42-year-old, who had a history of high blood pressure, was taken to hospital after falling ill while watching the movie.
He was unconscious when he arrived at the hospital and died 11 days later from a stroke.
“It’s likely that the overexcitement from watching the movie triggered his symptoms,” said Dr. Peng Chin-chih to AFP at the time.
There are more Avatar movies on the way. Source: AP
Snowtown - 2011:
The Aussie film about the “Bodies-in-Barrels murders” in South Australia turned out to be a health risk for some audience members when it was released.
One person fainted and about 20 people a week were leaving the cinema in distress, according to Cinema Nova general manager Kristian Connelly .
“People usually walk out because they’re bored, but this film makes people dash to the exit doors,” he said at the time.
“They can’t even cover their eyes or block their ears. They just want to leave and not return.
“A scene where it is suggested that a dog is about to be killed has caused the most consistent amount of people leaving the theatre, and yet the film has been particularly successful at Nova.”
Lucas Pittaway and Daniel Henshall in Snowtown. Source: Supplied
Originally published as Six films that made people sick in their seats
